snag.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a problem or disadvantage, especially one that is not very serious, which you had not expected
snag.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: It’s an interesting job. The only snag is that it’s not very well paid.
The grand opening hit a snag when no one could find the key.
snag.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: Snag is slightly informal. In written English, people usually prefer to use problem or disadvantage instead:
The only disadvantage is that it takes a little longer.
snag.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a part of a dead tree that sticks out, especially one that is under water and can be dangerous
snag.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a sharp part of something that sticks out and holds or cuts things that touch it
snag.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to damage something by getting it stuck on something sharp
snag.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Oh no! I’ve snagged my stockings.
snag.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to succeed in getting something, especially something difficult to get
snag.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: I snagged a parking space in the last row.
